He was a communicator, on paper and verbally. That seemed extremely strange. He'd been very ill [in 1968, Rothko had suffered an aneurysm, a result of his chronic high blood pressure]. When my mother told me what had happened on the phone, she did not tell me he had killed himself, and I presumed his death was due to one of the illnesses. So I was shocked.'

What was her father like? 'Oh, this is always a difficult one! He was a very social person, very outgoing.' In biographies, Rothko, who was born in Dvinsk, in what is now Latvia, and who arrived on Ellis Island, New York, in 1913, is always portrayed as a determined socialist. That is why he disapproved of the Four Seasons restaurant, and why he eventually decided to keep the paintings he made for its walls and later to give them to the Tate.

He also liked to make jokes about his peasant background. 'Well, part of that was just his humour. He liked to tell stories about his past. He was anything but a peasant. Education in the family went back three generations. He did remain close to his background. His family was never particularly supportive of his career, and didn't understand it, but there was always a weekly phonecall. He was pretty representative of immigrants of the time, in that he didn't retain his own language - I didn't even learn how to say yes or no in either Yiddish or Russian - but he would always go to the atlas and show me Latvia. He was a great storyteller. He used to tell me that he ice-skated to school. Knowing his athletic abilities, I suspect that was one thing he did not do.'

Kate was interested in his work from early on. Her parents had received membership of the Museum of Modern Art as a baby-shower gift and, on Sundays - after Mell insisted that Rothko leave his studio for the day - the family would go there. Later, Kate remembers visiting Peggy Guggenheim, the great patron and collector, in Venice. 'She took us to Torcello in her motorboat. But the story I always tell is about how, when I was 16, I went cross-country with my father by train. His family lived on the West Coast, and my mother would fly with my brother because he was so young. What is so frustrating, looking back, is that I had three days with my father and, had I been three years older, I would have taken the opportunity to talk to him about his philosophy. But, of course, we both sat there, and for three days, neither one of us really knew what to say to the other. It was an awkward age for me, and I think he felt that awkwardness. I look back and I think: what wasted time!'

Rothko's philosophy was, of course, complicated. He belonged to a generation of artists - his contemporaries included Pollock, Barnett Newman and Clyfford Still - who spent long periods in obscurity and poverty before they were discovered by the critics, at which point their prices rose - and rose. Perhaps this was why, post-1960, he found it so hard to accept his wealth. He paid cash for everything and, according to Robert Motherwell, if he had to go to the bank for any reason, he would slip into 'a depression as intense and prolonged as Kafka writing The Castle'.

But it was also that he worried that money would distract from the work itself; he distrusted material success. He was, as Robert Hughes has written, 'one of the last artists in America to believe, with his entire being, that painting could carry the load of major meanings and possess the same comprehensive seriousness as the art of fresco in the 16th century or the novel in 19th-century Russia... his painting accumulated resonance by appealing to myth; but myths were in decline....'

He was determined to think of himself as an outsider even as the riches and the praise - contemporary critics adored Rothko to the point of daffiness - heaped up at his studio door. Did these tensions - the sense you get from his work of a man waiting too long for an epiphany - contribute to his final depression, or was it also, as Lee Seldes suggests in her gripping book about the Rothko trial, that the artist knew that he had signed over too much to the Marlborough? His suicide took place on the same day that a representative from the gallery was due to visit Rothko's warehouse, to choose from the artist's hoard of paintings, something no one had ever done before (he liked to choose paintings for sale himself, and saw this visit, which he felt powerless to resist, as an invasion of privacy).

Kate is in two minds. 'I felt it had never quite sunk in how famous he had become,' she says. 'But then, when Pop art and Op art came so hard on their heels [of the Abstract Expressionists], he felt that he had had only a tiny window of fame, and then what? I think he would have been shocked by what happened after he died because he was absolutely convinced the executors were his friends, and that they'd act in the best interests of the estate. Whether he knew what was going on with the gallery is less clear. He knew he was not... free. I suspect things were planned for a while before he died. It seemed like everything was in place. I can't say if those pressures contributed to his mood, but they would certainly seem to have helped.'

Whatever lay behind her father's final destructive act, Kate hopes that Tate Modern's show will go some way to separating the work from the man, the paint from the biography. She would like people to see the late work as just that - late work - and to relish it for its own sake, the way we might the distinctive late bloom of any other artist, rather than regard it as a symptom of the dark clouds overhead. 'Even I have to step back from the biography at times,' she says. 'From my father as I knew him. Because, sometimes, that leads to misinterpretation.'

For me, the late paintings stand, as much as anything, as a corrective to the earlier work, with its warming yellows and pinks. They remind you that what Rothko most feared and disdained - the idea that his work was regarded as decorative - is too narrow, or at least too easy, a way of seeing him. They are the apotheosis of the existential struggle that lies at the heart of all his work.

And does his daughter still miss the man who gave us the paintings it has been her privilege to fight for, and to protect? I guess, thanks to his work, that her father lives on in a way that most people's parents do not. 'Yes. He does live on in that way. But the paintings are only one part of my father, and not the purely dad part. At family events, I still find myself thinking: I wish he could be here - though not, 38 years on, with the same tearfulness that I felt for... well, the first 20 years.'

Rothko's life in brief

1903 Marcus Rothkowitz is born in Latvia. Fearing their sons will be conscripted, the family emigrates to New York in 1913.

1935 Rothko joins with nine other artists to form the 'The Ten', with a mission 'to protest against the reputed equivalence of American painting and literal painting'.

1945 Marries Mary Alice Beistle, his second wife. Five years later Kathy Lynn is born; Christopher follows in 1963.

1959 Has his first one-man show in New York at the Museum of Modern Art.

1969 His Seagram mural paintings for the Four Seasons restaurant in New York are donated to the Tate.

1970 Commits suicide at the age of 66.

Actor Sadie Frost's clothing company FrostFrench changed hands for just £100,000 when it was bought out of administration last month.

The modest sum means the payout to creditors, who were owed £4.2m at the time of the collapse, will be in the region of only 2p in the pound.

The lingerie and accessories brand founded by Frost, the ex-wife of Jude Law, and her partner Jemima French, was rescued by a consortium of Norwegian investors who include John Joakim, a film producer.

The final dividend could rise as a result of the sale terms struck by the administrators, which included an 'earn-out' clause that entitles creditors to a 3 per cent share of the first year's takings of new venture FrostFrench London Retail, and 1.5 per cent in year two.

The design duo have promised to take a hands-on role in the new business. If they succeed in restoring sales to their previous high of £1.1m, the arrangement could hand suppliers another £50,000 over two years.

FrostFrench sells online and from its store in Islington. It also produces the Floozie range for Debenhams.

Gardai were hunting the gunman who killed a 24-year-old man in Dublin yesterday afternoon - the 14th gangland-related murder in the Republic so far this year.

The victim, named locally as Christopher Barry, was shot several times in the head while he stood in a bookmaker's on Killester Avenue in north Dublin. A lone gunman carried out the execution-style killing and then fled the scene on a motorbike. The vehicle was then found nearby set alight.

It is the second gun murder in the capital this week after 27-year-old Christopher McDonagh was shot dead on Wednesday at his west Dublin home. Eyewitnesses say the gunman 'strolled' from the bookies to the motorcycle he had pulled up on seconds earlier and rode off.

Friends of the dead man said he had been in the adjoining Ramble Inn pub with them earlier watching Manchester United take on Liverpool. They said he was not a drinker and had left a pint glass of orange juice at the bar to go to the bookies. The friends said he worked as a builder's labourer and his main sporting passion was pony trotting. They were bewildered as to why he was singled out and murdered.

Garda sources said it is possible that the dead man, who was wearing a distinctive yellow top, was a victim of mistaken identity. They asked anybody who saw anything to contact them at Whitehall Garda Station on 6664500 or use the confidential line on 1800 666 111.

As this paper's TV critic I daren't calculate how many hours I've spent in front of a television over the past nine years - it's both far too much and never quite enough. I'm still passionate about telly - as an advocate, a critic and a punter - and I think I've learnt quite a lot about the most powerful medium on the planet, but there's always more to know, so when I was recently given the opportunity to think inside the box for a change, I was intrigued.

Very unexpectedly I landed a job which promised to take me out of my own occasional onscreen comfort zone - offering up the odd sound bite - and into the clutches of an awesome primetime-reality beast. I was slightly scared by the idea but, of course, this was outweighed by my curiosity. Anyway, it's not like I was going to be a contestant

A couple of weeks ago at the Edinburgh TV Festival I watched a panel discuss celebrity culture - how and why our fascination with sleb trivia has taken a darker turn of late, post Britney and Amy Winehouse. Sharon Osbourne was insightful on how The Osbournes had worked brilliantly for her family but also how she feared for the (mostly) young women whose sole career aim is fame by any reality means necessary and sod the consequences.

I'm endlessly fascinated by this subject and guiltily consume as many reality formats as I can bear, so the opportunity to see how it might work from within was seductive. And while I may not be a contestant, I still had to audition and have a bunch of people decide, somehow and for reasons only they know (and which I'd probably rather not), that my face fitted. Which is how I now find myself one of a panel of three judges on a C4 reality show presented by Gok Wan and Myleene Klass, coming to a screen near you soon - and without giving too much away, after only one day of filming I have had virtually all my preconceptions about reality TV pretzel-twisted.

Around 9pm last Sunday, while in a heated off-camera debate with my (equally exhausted) fellow judges and the production team, it suddenly hit me: this wasn't merely an exercise in which I will get to find out what it's like to contribute to the most potent TV genre of the young and dumb 21st century, or simply have my ego tickled by the fact that I'm being treated fabulously by everybody with whom I come into contact, or even to find out if the celebrity presenters resemble their high-profile public personas (and they are, for the record, even lovelier). No, my light-bulb moment was suddenly realising that this discussion had ramifications above and beyond one small moment, that we three judges had been randomly gifted the power to change lives ... which seemed if not downright wrong then certainly faintly absurd. Suddenly this job - one for which my qualifications are negligible - felt like a big responsibility. The contestants are off on a thrilling voyage of self-discovery but, believe me, they're not the only ones who are learning fast.

I arrived on set prepared to make a TV programme, but I hadn't anticipated the monumental amount of effort, generosity of spirit and, most surprising - especially for a journalist - complete lack of cynicism from the huge team which makes this show. The attention to detail is not, as I had assumed, solely about manufacturing something diverting for an 8pm slot on Channel 4 by any means necessary - it is genuinely about making this as life-enhancing an experience for the contestants as possible. I don't (yet) understand the motivation to bare souls and more besides in front of strangers and cameras, but I'm desperately keen to find out.

It's a real privilege to work alongside people who appear to not only love television, but understand and respect its power. I love telly as a consumer, but since last Sunday I am learning to appreciate it in different ways as a participant. I really want our show (until yesterday I considered it to be somebody else's show) to be a fun, funny, warm, provocative, memorable, thought-provoking and intelligent piece of entertainment, ideally with a great big Happily Ever After at the end. Too much to expect? We'll see.

In 2003, the same year that he unveiled 'The Weather Project', his now legendary giant artificial sun that lit up the Turbine Hall at Tate Modern, Olafur Eliasson also created a much more intimately dramatic work of art. In a makeshift gallery at the Venice Biennale, he installed a white plastic drum that protruded from a wall with a red button on it that said 'PRESS'. Anyone who was brave or curious enough to press the button was startled seconds later by an intense flash of light from within the drum. For several minutes afterwards, each time the viewer blinked, the word 'UTOPIA' was imprinted on their retina. It was a work of art that literally made you see the world differently, and, as such, was both an illustration of and a metaphor for the Icelandic-born artist's methodology. Perhaps more than any other artist working today, Eliasson involves the viewer directly in the artworks he creates. 'My work is not about me,' he once said, 'it's about you.'

'The Weather Project' was the most successful single work of contemporary art exhibited in Britain in recent years, attracting an astonishing two million viewers to Tate Modern. More interesting still was the way in which the audience interacted with the piece. Many visitors wandered slowly through the Turbine Hall as if determined to take it all in, while others lounged on the floor for hours like sunbathers. Some days the atmosphere turned celebratory as crowds of strangers interacted by arranging their bodies to spell out giant words that were reflected on the mirrored ceiling. When Tim Neuger, Eliasson's gallerist in Berlin, visited Tate Modern, a group of young people had spelt out the words 'Fuck Bush' on the ceiling. He rang Eliasson in Berlin and let him listen to the cheers of the crowd echoing though the Turbine Hall.

You could say that Eliasson has reinvented the way in which conceptual art is received by the public, replacing the usual hushed reverence - or sighs of exasperation - with a mood of playful and anarchic mischief. 'I do not see my work as any kind of statement or a manifesto,' he says. 'It's a dialogue. Always.'

Right now, that dialogue is continuing apace, and with equally dramatic results, in New York, where Eliasson has created a series of giant self-propelling waterfalls on the East River. Situated at four different points between Manhattan and Brooklyn, the 'New York City Waterfalls' range in height from 90ft to 120ft, each pumping up to 35,000 gallons of water a minute up and over their giant frames. At night, they are illuminated, adding another level of surrealism to an otherwise drab stretch of the river. Eliasson's art attempts to make us see the everyday in a different light. 'In a way,' says Eliasson, 'I like to think that I have given New Yorkers back their river.'

And they, in their turn, have responded in kind. On the online photograph site, Flickr, visitors have posted more than 5,000 snapshots of the waterfalls, a mass response that pleases Eliasson much more than the chorus of excited approval that greeted the project's unveiling in the American media. 'On Flickr, the photographs have been taken mainly on mobile phones, and often there are people in the photographs with the waterfalls,' he says. 'It's a highly subjective way of documenting the work. I see the waterfalls as a co-producer of the time and place in which they take place. I suppose, in that way, the work filters into questions about society and democracy.'

This may indeed be the case, but it strikes me later, while perusing the images on Flickr, that the 'New York City Waterfalls' may also function as a kind of temporary tourist attraction that visitors pose in front of in much the same way that they pose in front of the iconic skyline or the Statue of Liberty further out in the harbour. In this way, Eliasson's artwork may well have slipped, like artworks have a tendency to do, out of the artist's control.

And for Olafur Eliasson, art does seem in a very real way to be about control. He frets a lot about how his work is interpreted to the point where he often tries to undercut the media's tendency to report what he does as mere spectacle. Or, as he puts it, 'I have a team that includes lawyers, copyright specialists, press officers, all making sure that the values I think the work represents are navigated into the communication of the project throughout the process. In my practice, I try my best to avoid the experience of my work being formalised, standardised, generalised and rationalised. My work is about the opposite.'

For someone who makes epic works of such sublime beauty - in itself quite a feat in an age when notions of the sublime in art sometimes seem as passé as pastels and watercolours - Eliasson is a doggedly serious, even earnest, young man. Talking to him about his art can be oddly exhausting. His mind, as his ambitious projects suggest, is in constant motion, one thought spiralling into another in ever-evolving circles of conceptual complexity. Like many installation artists, he has a tendency to theorise and his speech is littered with terms like 'duality' and 'collectivity', not to mention 'experiential'. He is the contemporary artist-as-boffin as well as architect, designer, philosopher and scientist.

'If one were to look for precedents as to the way Olafur works,' says Hans Ulrich Obrist of the Serpentine Gallery in London, where the artist created a pavilion last summer, 'it would have to be Buckminster Fuller, the artist-as-inventor. He has that kind of enquiring approach where the art emerges out of collective studio operation that is essentially a laboratory of ideas.'

To this end, Eliasson currently employs around 40 people in his Berlin studio, including architects and scientists as well as craftsmen and designers. It's all very Scandinavian, the notion of the unified aesthetic taken to conceptual extremes in the pursuit of art that is so ambitious in both its form and content that it engages the audience almost as much as it has engaged the minds of its creators. Before he installed his giant sun in Tate Modern, Eliasson's team constructed a small-scale version of the Turbine Hall, about 40ft long, in his studio so that they could wander through it and observe the effects.

'It's certainly unusual the way that he embraces all these various backgrounds to his art,' continues Julia Peyton-Jones, director of the Serpentine Gallery. 'Olafur's work addresses architecture, design, science and philosophy, and he operates at a very serious level. Of course, he has quite a big support team, but essentially it's his mind and his ideas that drive all these artistic investigations and makes his art what it is.'

I meet Eliasson in Copenhagen, where he has a big, bright, airy harbour-side office near the docks. He lives in the Danish capital with his wife and two adopted children when he is not working in Berlin, or flying around the world to oversee the various high-concept art projects he seems to be juggling at any given time. (In 1998, he had more than 60 artworks on show across the world.) Both his adopted son and daughter are Ethiopian, and he and his wife, the art historian Marianne Krogh Jensen, run a charity for Ethiopian orphans called 121Ethiopia.org. Recently, he designed a kind of mini art installation in the form of a light projection that will greet visitors to every Louis Vuitton shop on the planet - there are over 300. All the money earned from the commission went directly to his charity fund.

Currently, Eliasson is involved in an ambitious urban renewal project in Manhattan called the High Line and, earlier this summer he had a big retrospective of his work at MoMA. Alongside the architects Diller Scofidio+Renfro, he will help transform a mile-and-a-half stretch of disused elevated railway track into an elongated shopping mall with a park. Or, as the DS+R website puts it, 'a post-industrial instrument of leisure reflection'. You can see why Olafur gets along with them.

For the past two-and-a-half years, he has also been working on what he calls his 'academy'. The vast new office-cum-studio space he has just purchased in Berlin was formerly a school and, when it is converted, will house up to 20 student-apprentices who, Bauhaus-style, will learn how to be artists by being on-site and contributing to the Eliasson laboratory of ideas.

'Though all this is not related directly to making art, it is exciting and therapeutic,' he says, sounding genuinely enthused by the challenge. 'When you move studio, you can also optimise the values of the workplace. I can now give more space to the things that have turned out to be important and shed the less interesting things. A studio is not just a workspace but a little psychographic universe of the brain.'

At 40, Eliasson still has the air of the brainiest boy at school about him, and his chic wardrobe and designer spectacles somehow accentuate his palpable sense of studiousness. He was born in Denmark though both his parents are from Iceland, where his father worked as a cook on a fishing boat and a part-time artist, and his mother as a dressmaker. Interestingly, both his grandparents were bohemians: his grandfather published avant-garde writing, while his grandmother was a photographer of some local repute, and hosted a salon where Reykjavik's scattered artistic community gathered to argue and swap ideas. 'I am not avant-garde at all,' says Eliasson. 'I do not want to be a spokesman or lead a movement. I am essentially a traditionalist.'

Eliasson was four when his parents split up. A few years later, after his father moved back to Iceland, he began spending his summer holidays there with him. You sense that the country's elemental landscapes, strange sunlight and long shadows have had some deep and lasting effect on his creative psyche. As a teenager, he was a prolific drawer, specialising in anatomical sketches. By 14, he had also discovered breakdancing, which he seems to have embraced with the same fervour as he later pursued conceptual art. With his teenage posse, 'The Harlem Gun Crew', he toured Scandinavia, and even won the national break-dancing championship. Today, he is resolutely tight-lipped regarding his personal life, but recently he told the New Yorker that break-dancing 'really gave me a quite particular idea of space, and an obsession with how the body moves within that space'.

The same article had also revealed that, in 1987, his grandfather had committed suicide and that, as part of his university application, Eliasson had submitted a piece of sculpture in the form of a black gravestone.

He looks genuinely perturbed when I mention the New Yorker piece in passing. 'That was impossible for me. I mean, what was it about? And why on earth would anyone want to write a piece like that? The media do not know exactly how to verbalise something that does not anchor in the personal life of an artist. The music and fashion industry have promoted that idea for so long that it has become a model for how the media wants to address art.' He shrugs his shoulders and sighs. 'Also, I'm just not interesting enough to do that kind of profile on.'

This is a refrain that echoes throughout our conversation, and suggests that the incredible success of 'The Weather Project' and the 'New York City Waterfalls' has brought in its wake a level of exposure that Eliasson is utterly uncomfortable with. Earlier, when the subject of the YBAs, and Tracey Emin in particular, had come up, he had said, 'Emin is the opposite of me. Merging her life and her artwork completely is her greatest success, but I do not have those social skills. I am much more mainstream and boring. I am an uninteresting person really. I try to let the work go out there and not to require me to be in front of it.'

When I ask him who his formative influences were, he thinks for a moment, as if weighing up whether he should reveal them or not. Finally, he says, 'I started out being interested in the American west coast movement - Sol LeWitt, Donald Judd, Dan Flavin. Then, I came across the so-called land artists - Richard Long, Hamish Fulton.'

Eliasson's willingness to make epic artworks in the open air, though, recalls the work of Christo, who, back in the Seventies and Eighties, famously wrapped huge public buildings in fabric. Initially, though, after graduating from the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts, Eliasson expressed himself though photography: big Icelandic landscapes whose horizons and dimensions seemed askew. Soon, though, he moved into more ephemeral territory, using water, ice, steam and light in installations. In Venice, he also created the 'Yellow Room', which was lit by the kind of high-definition sodium lights that are used in Swiss motorway tunnels. He described, in his inimitable way, the experience of walking through it as 'hyper-seeing'.

More dramatic still was his now legendary act of interventionist or guerrilla art, the 'Green River' project, which consisted of dyeing rivers in various cities bright green. Using industrial amounts of the same vegetable dye that Irish-American bars use to colour the beer on St Patrick's Day, Eliasson managed to change the colour - at least for a brief moment - of rivers in Tokyo, Los Angeles and Stockholm. The impulse, he says, was the same one that drove the Waterfalls project. 'It makes the water explicit. You see the river differently. It shows that the river is a bloody river and not a postcard.'

Eliasson is quick to point out that, while the 'Green River' was 'an activist project', the 'New York City Waterfalls' is not. Does his work have an ecological agenda, as some have suggested? He sighs, but then concedes that this is an interesting question.

'With "The Weather Project", I ask myself that question all the time. I did not anticipate the global warming issue as it is today, it was more an attempt to set up ideas that would constitute a platform for collectivity. But the weather has become politicised. So, interestingly, the world has changed and the reading of my work has changed with it, but the work itself hasn't changed.'

He stares at my tape recorder for a long moment, as if lost in thought, then he says, 'One should be careful about only amplifying the ecological aspects of the waterfalls. I certainly don't consider myself an eco-warrior. Not at all. Talking about green power, that is for the brain. I'm not an intellectual artist, as you can see from my art. I make my work and then I talk about it. My work does not illustrate my ideas; my ideas try and support my work.'

Nevertheless, this is a man who initially wanted the Turbine Hall in Tate Modern to accommodate a tropical rainstorm as well as a giant sun. For once, though, the mechanics could not support the idea. The 'New York City Waterfalls', it strikes me, may well be that idea transformed. Indeed, one could view Eliasson's entire output as one unified work-in-progress.

'Olafur's process has to do with producing reality,' says Hans Ulrich Oberst, 'and that has taken him way beyond the exhibition space. He has an incredible sense of determination and a commitment to pursuing his ideas to see where they lead. With him, it's not so much about the destination but the journey itself.'

Towards the end of our meeting, I ask Eliassson, who has grown visibly restless, if he ever finds the time to daydream or be bored? He looks momentarily startled. 'When I am bored, I start doubting whether I exist,' he replies, without irony. 'When I don't do anything, I feel I might disappear.'

I ask him, in conclusion, if there might come a point when the bigness starts getting in the way of the art. 'Generally speaking, you are surely right,' he says, frowning and looking even more fretful, 'but one needs to challenge oneself and look deeper and ask oneself what role art has in society. To answer that question, one must take certain risks in order to reinvent what art can do. For me, the question is not how big or how small, but does the work succeed.'

The Celeb Diaries follows Mark Frith's near 10 years at Heat magazine. When Frith took the helm in early 2000, the magazine blossomed from being a disastrous flop to a hugely popular icon of our times. His mission was to 'debunk celebrities, make people realise they're just like you or me'. If Posh has a pimple or Gwyneth Paltrow reveals a bristly armpit, you can chortle about it in Heat

You soon get used to Frith's style of writing. Lots of 'Yeps!' and 'Bingos!' Indeed, you get so immersed in his world that when he describes a quote from Geri Halliwell as 'dynamite', you don't even question it.

The Celeb Diaries aspires, in look and subject matter, to be like Piers Morgan's The Insider (but without the Class A celebs or the self-congratulatory tone). Young Mark is a tad more downmarket, and in the end seems to feel almost as contrite about his line of business as we, the hungry readers, feel reading it.

What a job though. Imagine being able to stride into work on a Monday morning and shout, 'I want 25 pictures of celebs with cellulite on my table by lunchtime!' The 'bingo!' moments are good fun but given the somewhat exploitative nature of the beast I enjoyed the book most when things were going wrong for Frith. It's thrilling to hear how he sweated and squirmed on the phone to lawyers, or to witness his genuine dismay when Ewan McGregor describes Heat as a 'dirty piece of shit'. Go Ewan!

In a celebrity-obsessed society, this is a fascinating document. Nostalgic, too: remember when Jade was in Big Brother and everyone loved her? Rebecca Loos? What a girl! Jude and the nanny? That was a good one. It is interesting to discover just how the stories are unearthed and the scandal of the week chosen, and to marvel about how inconsequential they all were. Being the editor of such a magazine, the arbiter of what shocks and what rocks us, is no easy task. Frith - part man, part Jack Russell - had the energy and tenacity to last almost a decade. Someone should give him a bone (or a celebrity carcass) as a reward.

In the end it wasn't the pressure of the job that got to Frith but the ugly reality of celebs' lives: Britney in meltdown, images of Amy Winehouse in all her self- lacerated horror, and the reality of Mark Speight's fate. 'I was fed up of seeing pictures of tormented famous people,' he explains. We know how he feels.

The final straw, though, is pleasingly lightweight. It was John Barrowman who pushed him over the edge. The team's idea for a photo session was to make Barrowman look like Tom Cruise in Cocktail. 'John is not a poor man's Tom Cruise. He is a rich man's John Barrowman,' sniffed the agent. 'That's it. I'm resigning. This is not Madonna, this is John bloody Barrowman!' cried Frith. He had created a monster and no mistake.

Towards the end of the book the tone is surprisingly circumspect. 'The democratisation of fame has led to some of us going too far. When you see celebrities as your playthings ... how much do you play with them?' If the editor of Heat doesn't know the answer to that question, then who does?

The Celeb Diaries provoked an unexpectedly schizophrenic response in this particular reader. Although I am a celeb of sorts myself, I am mercifully of a calibre not often troubled by the attentions of Heat or any of the other, shall we say 'fame-orientated' magazines. (A photographer jumped out from behind a tree in Regent's Park the other day to pap me, but his heart wasn't in it. After three snaps he stopped and asked me if I knew where Kate Moss lived. As if.)

But even my lowly grading doesn't stop me feeling the hot glow of angry solidarity with Jude Law or Fern Britton when they have their privacy invaded, or when photos of their non-celeb relatives are published without their knowledge or consent. Yet, at the same time, I'm a punter at heart and my eye is drawn to a sordid headline or a shocking image as irresistibly as the next person's. I need my escapism too, and there is something brave and gloriously irreverent about a magazine genre that refuses to take itself or, more importantly, anyone else, too seriously.

You might describe it as camp - this obsession with all things trivial and aesthetic. Heat expresses no interest in serious news, happy or sad. Indeed, after 9/11 they worried that they might be out of business. Piers Morgan declared: 'I hear secretaries talking about anthrax and al-Qaeda, not EastEnders.' He was wrong, of course, for as Frith points out, 'They were talking about anthrax and EastEnders.' Sales went up that week by several thousand copies.

Statistics like this inevitably provoke hand-wringing, but there might be a more positive aspect to our appetites for celebrity disgrace. It does us the world of good to learn that our idols are flawed too, capable of wearing the wrong outfit, putting on weight, succumbing to temptation or just being plain unhappy like the rest of us. Most of all, Heat allows us to sympathise with the rich and famous - a whole new emotion. Sympathy is better and less painful than unrequited love or low-down envy. This may be Piers Morgan Lite, but if you've ever experienced the full-fat original, you'll know that may be no bad thing.

Here is a modest proposal: hand this book to FTSE 100 chief executives, private equity partners and hedge-fund managers in lieu of their annual bonus. I know that's never going to happen, but let's hope some will read it before they bank their seven-figure cheques.

The 'unjust rewards' of the title refers not only to the wealthy elite but to the poor, many of whom deserve better than the meagre wages and stunted life chances that are their lot in modern Britain. Birth, the authors argue, has become destiny. The predictive power of family background is greater than at any time since the Second World War; poverty has become a life sentence without parole.

Toynbee and Walker dissect the justifications of astronomical pay advanced by the recipients, who have agreed to participate in a City focus group. Those at the airless summit of the earnings scale are so stricken with money myopia they can barely believe most people make less than £40,000 a year, and are utterly nonplussed as to how anyone can survive in London on a mere £100,000. Yet they are keen to commandeer the moral high ground, suggesting they work harder and aim higher than nurses or teachers: after all, they have school fees to consider.

As the authors note, spending on offspring is seen as a trump card, as if it 'were automatically moral and good'.

Participants in the focus group are unlikely ever to cross paths with Alison Murray, one of 766,000 single mothers in the UK living on income support. She is a member of one of the most reviled groups in society, but she has been put in that position because she fell in love, got married and had babies. Her husband turned out to be violent and financially irresponsible, which would have been awful for a middle-class or wealthy wife, but not necessarily the full-scale disaster it has been for Alison.

'The rest of us, moneyed and/or lucky,' Toynbee and Walker write, 'may gamble, drink, choose a disastrous partner, fall into debt, behave badly or get pregnant unintentionally (most women do at some time). Friends forgive our faults, sympathise and accept that most people blunder sometimes. The mistakes of the poor make them society's problems, and the way they are then targeted for moral obloquy is one of the greatest inequalities of all.'

What really stood out for me was the book's hopeful side: the goodness and decency that stand against coarseness and greed. The ranks of the rich include intelligent people who want a fairer system: Sir Philip Hampton, chairman of J Sainsbury, is mentioned, and I could name others. A Middle England focus group, initially lacking insight into the lives of the poor, shifted their views when they learned more, stating that they would be prepared to pay 2p more in the pound in tax to provide a Sure Start children's centre in every neighbourhood. We learn about dedicated individuals, such as Faruk Noor of charity Tomorrow's People, who counsels the unemployed for depression. We also hear about the strength of the family in poor communities, resilient matrilineal constellations of grandmother, mother and children. Alison survives thanks to her mother, who buys her food claiming the items are 'on special', reducing her daughter to tears of gratitude.

The great strength of this book is not so much in the remedies it suggests, some of which are controversial, but in its appeal to the reader's imagination, sense of fairness and common humanity. In these credit-crunched times, there are all kinds of financial deficit in the City, but perhaps the deficit of imagination over how the other 99.99 per cent lives is the most damaging of all. It's enough to make you campaign for Asbos for the rich.

· Ruth Sunderland is Business Editor of The Observer

The dilemma I broke up with a girlfriend of four years a few months back because she was without doubt the most jealous woman I have ever met, and it was getting worse. (Although I never told her this, to spare her feelings - she is quite sensitive underneath the tough exterior.) She seems to have not let go and continues to tell everyone we are still together and are only taking time out. Things took on a darker note a week ago when I went for lunch with a colleague of mine and afterwards she told me that she had received several threatening phone calls from a woman. I'm fairly sure it was my ex. Tell me what to do: am I being paranoid or overreacting, because I'm afraid of this escalating

Mariella You clearly need to have a full and frank discussion with your ex, but humour me a little first. Let's talk about one of the most corrosive emotions to afflict any relationship, as you discovered - jealousy. Whether it's justified or imagined, the green-eyed monster is a very scary beast indeed. I've seen it cow perfect relationships into submission and destroy a few of my own along the way.

Like acne, jealousy is most frequently found and certainly only acceptable in youth, though it's all but guaranteed to exist at terrifying levels not only in adolescent but early adult relationships, too. There can be few of us who emerged from our twenties without at some time or other succumbing to the insidious, debilitating and incredibly destructive effects of imagined, potential or, worst of all, proven infidelities. Happily, the latter tends to be the least likely scenario of the three.

When you're caught in its steely grip, jealousy seems the perfectly rational side-effect of true passion. You're in love, which is a risky business, and therefore you must protect your territory as though it were the last oil field on earth. There are many things wrong with that theory - not least the notion that love is something you can claim possession of and then keep hold of by ring fencing it from any other potential takers. Nobody ever stuck around solely because you managed to eradicate all temptation. The most accomplished control freak in the universe couldn't protect a relationship for an entire lifetime. If anything, the partnerships who enjoy long-term success tend to be those where the connecting fibres are surprisingly lax. I'm not talking about that flawed utopian ideal of the open relationship, rather that when two adults allow expectations of decency and respect to dictate their behaviour (rather than their psychotic subconscious), things tend to go more smoothly.

If you're unfortunate enough to end up with a strayer, there is no security system on earth that will keep them faithful - and only heartbreak ahead for the partner who makes it their life mission to cling on. With that in mind there is nothing less dignified than an adult man or woman displaying the symptoms of irrational jealousy. If you're so afraid your partner is going to stray that you need to scare off any adult who appeals, then there is either something very wrong with you or with your relationship. Maturity leads most rational adults to the conclusion that jealousy is not an indication of the depth of feeling involved or an emotion to be coveted. Rather it's as clear an indication that things are awry as incessant arguing or a complete absence of physical contact.

For the sake of one's pride alone, jealousy is worth eradicating from the equation. To spend the little time you have consumed by the terrible dread that you are about to lose everything you love in ghastly circumstances is no way to lead a fulfilling life.

The jealousy sufferer is always on the wrong foot, too. Either they are imagining infidelities where none exists - which makes them the weaker partner, vulnerable and ultimately en route to destroying their relationship - or their fear is based on real betrayal, and equally unhelpful. Jealousy doesn't make you strong, angry or better able to deal with a cheating partner; it makes you insecure, bitter and stressed.

So to you and your potential bunny-boiling ex. I'm unclear why you spared her feelings when you broke up: most people would far rather be given a tangible cause for being chucked than the banal 'It's not working'. You need to tell her, in no uncertain terms, that her jealousy poisoned your relationship and will ruin her life until she gets a grip. Clearly you also need to make plain that you have moved on and that you hope she has, too. You may never know if she was the deranged caller, but you can make sure you're not to blame for sending her confusing messages. If she's brandishing a zealot's confidence that you are hers to lay claim to, you need to make very plain
that you are an independent state and will not be walled off like some unfortunate human manifestation of the West Bank.

If you, too, have a dilemma, send a brief email to mariella.frostrup@observer.co.uk

The Case Study

Hey, I strike you as that kind of guy, right?' It is an early morning in late August and Morgan Spurlock, documentary film-maker, the man who in his breakthrough film, Super Size Me, pushed his body to the absolute brink by dining on nothing but McDonald's for a month, unleashes the first of many manly laughs. Less than 24 hours earlier he was at the Democratic National Convention, where he attended a Rock the Vote party, plugged his new film, Where in the World is Osama bin Laden? and - as Record Doctor is none too surprised to learn - listened to his current favourite band the Hold Steady for the duration of the plane journey home.

'For me,' he says, listing the quintet's qualities, 'it's all about the lyrics, the music, the structure; the way that he [frontman Craig Finn] writes songs that tell stories which hark back to old songwriting styles. They're just... awesome.'

'Awesome' is a word that crops up a lot when talking with the New York-based 37-year-old. NERD, and especially Pharrell, are 'pretty awesome'. Cypress Hill are 'awesome'. The Sex Pistols too. He's equally fond of 'blew up' and 'busted out', making Spurlock sound like an improbable amalgam of bubbly, backslapping revolutionary ('Do I like music with "fuck you" qualities? Oh absolutely!') and all-American perpetual adolescent. Tellingly, Foreigner soundtracked his early teens.

'They were a big band for me. Come on,' he says, detecting a note of disbelief in Record Doctor's voice, 'when you hear "Jukebox Hero" and "Hot Blooded", how can you not be excited?' None the less, they proved to be a major disappointment when in Tennessee, in 1984, he saw them on their Agent Provocateur tour. 'It was all (sings), "I wanna know what love is", with' - he adopts a tone of utter disgust - 'this huge, like, choir behind them. I'd have loved to have seen them in 1980 when they were all strung out and rocking.'

Spurlock derives his love of hard-rocking bands from his two brothers, particularly the eldest, a Black Sabbath/Led Zep aficionado. This was unusual in West Virginia, where everyone loved country including Spurlock's father. Especially his father. Spurlock, though, loathed it.

'It felt like nails down a chalkboard to me. My dad would get into his car, put some country on and sing along, a cigarette in his mouth, and I'd be like (shouts), "C'mon! Kill me! Enough already!"' And then, in his late teens, he moved away from home. 'Something changes when you go out into the world - things open up. Now I love Willie Nelson and Merle Haggard. Awesome.'

Spurlock has undergone several conversions since, aged eight, frequenting a Dr Hook concert ('I was so excited just to, like, be there'). He bought his first single when 'I was nine or 10' - Rick James's 'Super Freak', a huge hit with his mum. Hall and Oates followed along with Foreigner before, after flirting with Metallica and hip hop ('I remember when it first busted out'), the Red Hot Chili Peppers and 'protest music', he acquired a slot on college radio in New York.

'And that's when I got turned on to this whole other world, all these great English groups - the Smiths, XTC and the Stone Roses.' He became smitten, too, with a fellow student, a fan of a band of whom he'd never heard: REM. 'I'll be thankful to her for ever for introducing me to them,' he says, trying, fruitlessly, to remember the album that functioned as his portal into Michael Stipe's world. 'I can recall hearing him [Stipe] for the first time and thinking that he didn't sound like anyone else I'd been turned on to before.'

Since then music has changed immeasurably, he says, largely for the better - thanks to the internet. 'Suddenly you're finding out about some guy in Kansas making music in his garage whom no one had ever heard of before. And there's something very special about that.' Not so the way in which music is now consumed. 'Remember when albums would come out and you and your friends would sit around and listen together?' He sighs and recounts his introduction to the Pistols' 'Anarchy in the UK' and Cypress Hill's self-titled debut set. 'I miss that,' he says, momentarily sombre. 'A shared music experience is beautiful.'

He didn't feel that way, mind, when a few weeks ago he went with a pal to an avant-garde gig. 'Someone was banging on a pot while someone in the background went (makes ghost-like noise), "Woooh ooohh ooohh!" I said to my friend: "If you ever invite me to anything like this again, I will kill you."'

While he has little interest in banging on a pot, Spurlock is learning, slowly, to play the banjo. Very, very slowly. He has owned one for two years.

'I've got this series of albums called Pickin' On - bluegrass versions of rock classics. Have I mastered any?' He laughs. 'No. I've just mastered keeping it in the closet and not practising. But if I do... well,' he says, 'that would be pretty awesome.'

The Symptoms - his favourites

Metallica
Last Caress (Elektra)

'This song has soundtracked many moments of angst and inspiration in my life. I love music that can both transport me back and push me forward at the same time. And it still kicks ass.'

Johnny Cash
Folsom Prison Blues (Columbia)

'He's the Man in Black, enough said. The first rebel of rock'n'roll and someone who marched to his own tune all the way to the end. And anyone who can write a line like "I shot a man in Reno, just to watch him die" is someone worth listening to.'

.38 Special
Hold on Loosely (A&M)

'Whenever I hear this song, I crank up the stereo and rock out. What can I say? You can take the boy out of West Virginia, but you can't take West Virginia out of the boy.'

Louis Armstrong
Do Nothin' Till You Hear From Me (Universal Classics)

'I got turned on to Satchmo as a child and have loved him ever since. He was the reason I wanted to play trumpet at 13 and he always makes me smile. If I was stranded on an island, I'd want a collection of his music. It is timeless.'

The Diagnosis

The Patient's first purchase was Rick James's 'Super Freak'. Would Meshell Ndegeocello's 'I'm Diggin' You (Like an Old Soul Record)' revive memories of his foray into funk?

Rilo Kiley's Jenny Lewis is no conventional country balladeer, but her solo work, as evidenced by 'Rise Up With Fists!', is flavoured with elements of the South. In contrast, The Week That Was ('The Airport Line') could not be more English, their stately pop perfect, on paper at least, for a sometime Anglophile.

REM are, perhaps, the Patient's favourite band and, on the strength of 'Revolution (in the Summertime)', they are Cosmic Rough Riders' favourite band too.

Among the qualities that the Patient admires is an aversion to timidity and Julian Cope's 'All the Blowing Themselves Up Motherfuckers (Will Realise the Minute They Die That They Were Suckers)' is brave, unquestionably, if inflammatory.

Finally, while the Patient undoubtedly adheres to John Lennon's maxim, 'avant-garde is French for bullshit', he might feel differently about CocoRosie whose 'K-Hole', crucially, is goth-folk with a tune.

The Cure

Julian Cope has been called a lot of things in his life, among them 'nutbag' and 'headwear obsessive'. To the Patient's mind, though, he is a 'genius'.

'I have become a huge fan of the Brian Jonestown Massacre and when I hear this track, it's easy to see the road that was paved for them by people like Cope.'

His other big favourites were the Cosmic Rough Riders, whose album 'I bought right after I heard this. I love guitar-wielding troubadours from the past and this track is at the crossroad of old and new.'

The Patient was already au fait with Jenny Lewis, having become a 'recent convert' on the strength of an appearance on TV in the States. 'I love voices like hers, plus the lyrics are fantastic.'

The Patient knew all about Meshell Ndegeocello, too, but while 'I like her stuff, and if I were dancing in a club I would seriously get my funk on, I wouldn't rush out to buy this'.

Neither would he invest in The Week That Was ('It's as if Toto had been reincarnated. I loved Toto; this not so much'), while CocoRosie, sadly, left him scratching his head. 'Actually being in the k-hole may increase listening pleasure, I think.'

We haven't been driving around the outskirts of Memphis for too long before Seasick Steve spots a neighbourhood he thinks he recognises. Something about the weather-beaten houses set back off the dusty road is tugging at his memory.

'Most everything has changed round these parts but this place looks familiar,' he says, sounding suddenly excited. A little further along, we crest a hill and a silver grain silo looms up behind a tall wire fence and suddenly we're at a railroad crossing. Up ahead, a wooden sign in the shape of an x says, 'Prospect'. All the while, Seasick Steve is bouncing up and down on his seat and whooping with delight like a child.

'Goddamn!' he shouts, jumping out of his pick-up. 'This place ain't hardly changed a bit since I used to come down here and try and hop a freight train going north.'

We walk along the tracks for a bit, over a concrete bridge that straddles a dank, dark stretch of river. In one direction, there is nothing but railroad track stretching off to infinity; in the other, maybe 200 yards away, there's a big freight train, way over 16 coaches long, stationary and silent. Seasick Steve is pacing up and down the track in his jeans and braces, check shirt and workman's boots, and pulling at his grey hobo beard. He looks lit up, excited. 'Whoooee!' he shouts. 'Ain't that something? It's like they knew we was coming and they ordered us up a train!'

A few minutes later, as if on cue, the freight train shudders to life and comes rolling up the track real slow. It judders to a halt right in front of us, and a switchman jumps off the engine and gets to work on the tracks with his lever. Then, the train grinds into action once more, and Seasick Steve is shouting, 'You hear that! Whoaaah! Yes indeed!', and it's as if he is hearing the past unfolding.

As the train rolls by, wagon by wagon, he points at one carriage where there is a flat, steel platform on the back. 'See that? Right there! That's where you hop the train as it's moving slow out of the yard and then you gotta lie low till you're out of the neck of the yard and hope the bulls [railroad police] don't see you. Then, you're gone, man! Straight to Chicago or Chattanooga or wherever that train's gonna take you.'

He stands staring after the freight train as it disappears into the distance. You can tell he would like to be on board, hunkering down between the wagons. Then he turns to me and says: 'Don't you see, man? You can jump up on one of those and you're gone! Outta here. Someplace else. For free!' I nod, but what the hell do I know about that kind of freedom or the hardship that attends it? All I have to go on is what I've glimpsed in the songs of Woody Guthrie, Jimmie Rodgers, Boxcar Willie and their unlikely successor, this rough and tumble character standing before me on the dusty tracks he once stalked like a ghost, and now stalks again, 40 years later, in song.

Back in the pick-up, still excited, he starts singing softly. It's a song called 'Prospect Lane' from his new album, I Started Out With Nothin' and I Still Got Most of it Left. A song that was born right here on this train track leading out of Memphis, Tennessee, maybe 40 years ago, and has taken all this time to come to life.

'I got my ear down to the ground
Listening for the rumbling sound,
Deliver me from this town,
Today, I'm gonna be homeward bound
Whoaa, waiting for the train,
Today, yesterday, it's just the same
Down at the end of Prospect Lane...'

The following night, after we have driven down Highway 61, past acres of raggedy corn where there were once only fields of cotton for as far as the eye could see, and we are holed up in the Shack Up Inn on the other side of Clarksdale, Mississippi, drinking cold beer and fighting a losing battle with some badass mosquitoes, I finally ask Seasick Steve how he felt down there by the tracks. He shakes his head and sighs.

'Kinda melancholy is how I felt,' he says, his hoarse, weather-beaten voice no more than a whisper. 'So much stuff don't look the same any more, but that place did. So, it was strange, man. Exciting, but kind of melancholy too.' He falls silent for a moment or two. 'I guess I miss it, that old freedom,' he says, finally, 'but I don't want to retrace it too much 'cept in the songs. You can't relive the past, man. Can't go back there. You go back a day later and it's changed. Forty years later and it's like a dream you once had.'

Forty years ago, Seasick Steve was a hobo whose constant wandering brought him down here to the Deep South more than once. At 13, he had fled his home in Oakland, California, on the run from a violent stepfather who, in a fit of rage, had thrown him though the window of his mother's house. 'I had a moment of revelation,' he says. 'It was like I had been pushed right to the edge by what was happening to me, and I knew I was going to have to kill that motherfucker. Then, I suddenly thought: "No, Steve, it don't have to be like that. You don't have to end up in jail for one reckless act." It suddenly hit me that there was another way out. I could just run, and keep running. That way, at least my life would be my own.'

Back then, Memphis was the hub of the South, a place where you could hop a train to almost any town in America. Some of the giant train yards still remain: The Tennessee Yard, The Burlington Northern Yard, The Johnston Yard. But like the city itself, the railroad is but a shadow of its former self, a repository of memories for anyone old enough to remember a time when, as a nostalgic Tom Waits once told me, 'everywhere you went in America, there seemed to be a train crossing.'

Back then, Seasick Steve was plain Steve Wold from Oakland, California, and it was music not trains that he was chasing. One of his earliest memories is of his father playing boogie-woogie piano, Pinetop Perkins-style. 'Got a picture of me, just two years old, sitting on the old man's knee while he played the boogie,' he says, a sad smile on his grizzled face. 'My dad loved that shit and I guess he passed some of it on to me.'

The shack we are sitting in is part of a themed blues bed and breakfast set-up owned by two Mississippi hippies called Guy and Bill, but it once belonged to the old Hopson Cotton Plantation, where Pinetop Perkins worked. In one of the adjacent shacks, Pinetop taught the young Ike Turner to play the piano. Further on up the road is Clarksdale where, legend has it, Robert Johnson supposedly sold his soul to the devil down at the crossroads at midnight. It's also where Sam Cooke was born, and where the great Bessie Smith died after a car crash out on Highway 61.

'I came down here as a young feller looking for the blues, but I didn't find them,' says Seasick Steve, laughing and taking a swig from a small bottle of Tennessee bourbon. 'Wasn't in Clarksdale but an hour before a big, old redneck policeman ran me right out of town again. That was how it was back then, and there were some places hereabouts you just didn't go if you were a hobo. No sir. But, I love it down here. It's where it all starts. Charlie Patton, Son House, Mississippi Fred McDowell, ol' Pinetop, they all hail from round here. Right here where we're staying, the atmosphere is so thick with old ghosts that I get almost drunk when I breathe the air.'

You can hear some Mississippi ghosts in Seasick Steve's music, too, in the raggedy thrust of his old-fashioned songs, in the broken down swagger of his playing. Down the road in Como lives his old friend Sherman Cooper, 'a pack rat with a house full of junk'. A few years back, Sherman gave Seasick Steve an old three-string guitar that he'd picked up somewhere and nailed to the wall as an ornament of sorts. When Seasick Steve's wife Elizabeth saw it for the first time, she said: 'That guitar is going to make you famous.' Steve laughed, and he's still laughing now - all the way to the bank.

The Three-String Trance Wonder, as it is now called, has since become his trademark. Likewise the One-Stringed Diddley Bow, basically a plank with a single string, which was made for him by another eccentric local musician, James 'Super Chikan' Johnson. Then there's the Mississippi Drum Machine, which is basically a wooden box for stomping time on. Steve has customised it with a piece of carpet and a Mississippi license plate. He's a showman as well as a storyteller, and someone who is acutely aware of the power of his own mythology, and how it has to be maintained.

'I like to keep things kind of rough and basic,' he says. 'That's what the young kids like. They're tired of being sold all this smoothed-out, cleaned-up shit. In a way, my music's kind of like a punk. Old, smelly, punk.'

Seasick Steve's late success has surprised no one more than himself, and he tells me more than once that he doesn't really expect it to last but he's going to try to make himself 'some real money' while it does. Though both his songs and his persona trade heavily on his hobo credentials, he actually turned his back on the road way back in 1973. 'It just got too damn hard,' he says, 'and I knew if I kept on, I'd end up dead in a ditch somewhere.' The trajectory of his life since then is hazy and, one suspects, he plays down the semi-settled years, sensing correctly that his mainly young audience prefer the myth to the reality.

For the past 35 years, he has worked, on and off, in the music business, both as a hired session musician and as a studio engineer. Along the way, he has played with Joni Mitchell and, when he lived for a while in Olympia, near Seattle, in the late Eighties, helped produce albums for 'damn near every grunge group in America'. Though he has been married to his second wife for 27 years, and has five grown-up sons, Steve has had some trouble putting down roots in one place. 'I'm a settled hobo' is how he puts it, adding that he and his wife have lived in 59 different houses to date. They are currently based in Norfolk, which, he assures me, 'is a whole lot more exciting than Norway'.

It was in the Norwegian town of Notodden, however, that he found himself living four years ago. There he started recording a bunch of songs on a four-track tape machine. He was recovering from a heart attack that had left him feeling 'hopeless and helpless', and tells me he 'didn't have no big plans for the songs 'cept for giving them to my wife'.

The results found their way to his old friend, Joe Cushley, a DJ on internet radio station Resonance FM, who passed them on to the small British independent label, Bronzerat Records. Towards the tail end of 2006, Seasick Steve got a call from the BBC, who wanted him to appear on Later... with Jools Holland. Though he had no idea who Jools Holland was, he was persuaded to perform one song, 'Doghouse Boogie', on his New Year's Eve Hootenanny. It caused a stir in the studio, and an even bigger one online. A few days later, Seasick Steve's website collapsed under the weight of several thousand hits. The most unlikeliest cult star of the Noughties was born: an ex-itinerant pensioner who played the shit out of a three-stringed guitar miked up with gaffer tape.

'I was shocked, man,' he says now, laughing his big throaty laugh and tugging on that long beard. 'It wasn't a good performance. I couldn't see nobody, couldn't hear nobody. I just threw my old guitar down at the finish in frustration. Then, all hell broke loose.'

After the Jools Holland show, Seasick Steve, suddenly found himself in demand. He played a series of festivals across Europe, and his first record, Doghouse Music, started selling well. In 2007, he won a Mojo magazine award for Best Breakthrough Act. The weekend before we met, he had gone down a storm at the Reading Festival, playing to 65,000 people, all of whom seemed to be singing along. He is just about to embark on a sold-out tour of Britain.

'I still have a moment every day where I have to stop and take stock of what's happened and I still ain't figured it out,' he says. 'I got people coming up to me all the time in England. Young girls getting fresh! It's weird, man, them girls just see a star, they don't see an old guy.'

It says something about the times we live in that Seasick Steve has managed to slip, mostly by word-of-mouth success, through into the mainstream. In doing so, he has become a hero to a generation for whom the word 'hobo' is about as meaningless as the word 'blues'. What they see in him is something that's long gone, something they can only ever experience vicariously through the rough energy of his songs.

Refreshingly, the object of their devotion doesn't give a hoot about 'authenticity', and rejects the loaded term 'blues singer' outright. 'I'm an entertainer,' he says. 'I tell stories but my stories are real. I give 100 per cent of myself every time I walk onto a stage. Don't matter if it's 10 people or 10,000, I want to make them remember me.'

Seasick Steve is cagey about his actual age, but looks like he might be hitting 70. If his new album makes it into the charts, which it may well do given the seemingly unstoppable momentum of his success, he will be the most unlikely pop star of the download and digital age. 'Imagine if I had to pitch myself to a record label boss,' he says, laughing. 'It'd be like, "OK, here's the deal. I'm gonna play old time country-blues on this here piece of shit guitar and I gonna be a pop star." He gonna be reaching for the phone straightaway. "Can you take this old guy outside. He smells."'

Over at Warner Music, though, the corporate marketing machine has rolled into gear behind Seasick Steve's new album, secure in the knowledge that he is already a cult figure on the verge of breakthrough status. 'They put some serious pressure on me to use a regular producer,' says Steve. 'They even had this feller, Youth, lined up, but I said no. I want to make it the way I hear it.'

One of the best songs on the album, 'Just Like a King', features Grinderman, Nick Cave's other band. 'I asked Nick to write a verse,' says Steve, 'and he just looked out the window, twirled his chair for a few minutes, then started writing. It's a damn good verse, too.' More affecting still is the autobiographical blues ballad, 'My Youth', which, though just a fragment of a song, mines a whole seam of sadness and regret that many of his more rambunctious songs do not touch on. 'I got my memories,' he sings, over a lonesome slide guitar, 'and that's something no one can steal.'

A few months ago, he tells me, he hopped a train from Nashville to Chattanooga and back 'just for the hell of it'. How did that feel? 'Kinda peaceful. I got on and it was just like before. The only difference is there ain't nobody doing it any more. I asked an engineer if he'd ever seen any hobos. He said, "No, but a friend of mine has a book about 'em." He'd been working the railroad for 10 years, never seen one. Ain't that something?'

The second night we spend in Mississippi, to the surprise of a handful of guests, Seasick Steve plays an impromptu set in a big barn at the Shack Up Inn. He is joined on stage by two young local blues musicians, guitarist Lightning Malcolm and drummer Cedric Burnside, son of Calvin Jackson, and grandson of the legendary Mississippi guitarist, RL Burnside. The show is intriguing on many levels. The three musicians have never played together before, nor have they even rehearsed, but there is some serious chemistry between them all the same, and the show smoulders and eventually ignites, delighting an audience of about 20 people. Throughout, Cedric has a smile on his face that's as wide as the Mississippi, but Malcolm watches Seasick Steve like a hawk, following wherever he leads. It's the blues, all right, but not as we have come to know it.

'We knew what we was doin' from the moment we started,' Seasick Steve tells me later. 'We didn't talk too much about it, but I knew they was going to get it. It's an understanding. I guess you'd call that the blues. Way I see it, you can call it whatever the hell you want, long as people listenin' to it. Hell, there was a time back there when there weren't nobody listenin'. Seemed like every time I picked up a guitar, I could clear the room in seconds flat. I guess you keep at it long enough, the world eventually comes around to your way of thinking.'

Kings of the Road: Those hobo hit-makers

Seasick Steve is a self-declared hobo - a term whose etymology is far from clear but which refers to the subculture of itinerant railroad riders who proliferated in America from the end of the Civil War in 1865 through until the Great Depression of the 1930s and beyond. Figures who at some point counted themselves as hobos include author Jack London, boxer Jack Dempsey and the film star Robert Mitchum.

Celebrated hobo musicians have included Woody Guthrie, composer Harry Partch, rockabilly pioneer Johnny Burnette, country singer Boxcar Willie (real name: Lecil Travis Martin) and folk singer Utah Phillips (who died earlier this year). Chief among the canon of hobo songs must be Roger Miller's 1965 hit 'King of the Road', subsequently covered by everyone from Elvis Presley to Boney M and Rufus Wainwright. There is also Bob Dylan's 'I Am a Lonesome Hobo', 'Only a Hobo' and 'Ramblin' Gamblin' Willie', Captain Beefheart's 'Hobo Chang Ba', John Lee Hooker's 'Hobo Blues' and 'The Hobo' and Paul Simon's 'Papa Hobo', as well as the Doobie Brothers' 'Long Train Runnin" and even Jethro Tull's 'Aqualung'.

· Seasick Steve's new album I Started Out With Nothin' and I Still Got Most of it Left (Warner) is released on 29 September. He plays the Royal Albert Hall, London SW7 on 1 October and tours the UK thereafter.

As a panacea for defeat in the first Old Firm match of the season, a comprehensive victory at a traditionally difficult place like Motherwell would have been entirely satisfactory to those Celtic supporters who watched their team give one of their best displays of this year.

The irresistible surges of a first half in which they built a 4-0 lead thanks to two goals from Georgios Samaras and one each from Scott McDonald and Shaun Maloney left the home side looking likely to face utter humiliation. But Motherwell's comeback, with goals from John Sutton and David Clarkson, brought them respectability and threatened, briefly, to bring about a minor miracle.

Gordon Strachan's changes to the Celtic team amounted to punitive action against those who had performed so poorly against Rangers two weeks ago, but he could not have imagined the newcomers could effect such a transformation. There was a sharpness and commitment about Celtic from the opening seconds and, in that respect, expectations could not have been more spectacularly fulfilled.

The restoration of McDonald to the attack, the introduction of the young Spaniard Marc Crosas to midfield and the recall of Lee Naylor to left-back, with Mark Wilson moving to his more comfortable role on the right, seemed to galvanise the champions.

Motherwell were made to look like trees as the green and white shirts breezed past, the ball under control, the space opening up and the exploitation of the opportunities utterly ruthless. For a team whose morale was supposedly on the point of disintegration after the defeat by Rangers, Celtic were strikingly ebullient.

Usually a difficult venue, Fir Park, on this occasion, proved to be a soft touch, perhaps, in part, because of the new playing surface, which has rid the stadium of its reputation as the home of the most damaged, and least accommodating, pitch in the country.

Samaras and Scott Brown certainly could not have moved more smoothly as they combined down the right for the series of passes that would bring the opening goal. Brown finished the sequence with a low cross to the far side of the six-yard box, where Maloney, quite isolated, left-footed the ball into the unprotected net.

Samaras would deliver the first of his goals when he received McDonald's pass, brushed past two defenders and slid the ball low past Graeme Smith with his left foot. McDonald provided the third when he received a throw-in from Wilson on the right, quickly turned and hit a brilliantly controlled volley, with the outside of his right foot, high past Smith.

Celtic's dazzling movement was typified by the fourth goal. Naylor moved down the left and played the ball forward to McDonald, who back-heeled it into the path of Samaras. The towering Greek, moving at top speed, took the pass in his stride, covered another 20 yards and drilled the ball, right-footed, low to the left of the goalkeeper.

In the circumstances, Motherwell's second-half performance could be called astounding. There was renewed vigour about their work from the start and the goals they produced, in a two-minute period soon after the restart, were the least their efforts deserved.

There seemed to be no major threat when Clarkson lobbed the ball into the Celtic area, but it broke to Sutton, who hit a right-foot volley powerfully and low to the left of Artur Boruc.

Stephen Hughes, the most creative of the Motherwell midfield players, then played a through-ball to Clarkson, who beat Gary Caldwell and Boruc in the chase, stretched out his right leg and slid the ball past the goalkeeper from 10 yards out.

Gianfranco Zola has promised to try to deliver as a manager as much entertainment - along with some of the success - as he did as a player, and there was plenty for him to admire from his new team in this rousing match.

West Ham were a goal down before Zola had a chance to settle into his seat in the directors' box. Then they lost Dean Ashton, whose run of injuries shows no sign of coming to an end after he was forced off early on with an ear wound that required six stitches.

The response was commendable and arguably merited some reward. But in the end it was Tony Mowbray celebrating on the touchline as Albion recorded their first victory, after a stuttering start to the season, with a tremendous late winner from Chris Brunt.

Zola had a quick, consoling word with his players afterwards. Caretaker manager Kevin Keen, who now waits to see what the future holds for him, said: 'He thought we were unlucky not to get something. It was disappointing for the players, who put so much into the match. Their reaction to going behind so early and to the loss of Dean was great. The most disappointing thing was conceding a goal so soon after we had gone ahead.'

Keen kept his counsel on that penalty conceded by goalkeeper Robert Green, but maintained: 'Robert is as honest as they come and he insists he got the ball.'

Mowbray was delighted with the points, which he feared his side would struggle to collect when injuries to Abdoulaye Méïté and Gianni Zuiverloon and a debut for £800,000 signing Jonas Olsson from NEC Nijmegen meant a major defensive reshuffle.

'There were some good points, but other areas where we must improve,' said Mowbray. 'We have to control matches more. This gets us up and running. Now let's see whether we can go on and get into the pack.'

James Morrison beat Matthew Upson to head West Brom in front from a cross by record signing Borja Valero on his home debut. West Ham, with Herita Ilunga on loan from Toulouse making a solid debut at left-back and David Di Michele, on loan from Torino, doing well when replacing Ashton, levelled when Calum Davenport crossed to the far post for Di Michele to head goalwards. Scott Carson pushed the ball out and Mark Noble put it back in.

It got better for them, Upson knocking down a corner for Lucas Neill to fire home off Morrison on the goalline. But two minutes later Lee Probert ruled that Green had brought down Leon Barnett and Roman Bednar converted the resulting penalty.

The cut and thrust continued. Carlton Cole turned Olsson and sent Luis Boa Morte in on goal, but Carson stood up well to block his near-post shot. Then, Green went down at the feet of Bednar to prevent West Brom regaining the lead.

The decisive goal was good enough to win any match. Albion broke from defence through Robert Koren and Paul Robinson and the finish by Brunt, low into the far corner when under pressure, did justice to the build-up.

West Ham were not finished and it needed a save by Carson to deny Scott Parker, who nevertheless will be kicking himself for placing his effort from close range too near the keeper.

THE FANS' PLAYER RATINGS AND VERDICT

Terry Wills, Baggies@yahoogroups.com

Boing! Boing! Boing! I know nine out of 10 reports will be about West Ham and Zola, but this was a very entertaining game that we just about deserved to win in the end. The atmosphere was tremendous and the football, at times, was brilliant from both teams. A goal after two minutes always helps and we played some tremendous attacking football in the first 25 minutes. It was a shock to go 2-1 down, but the penalty came at the right time and from then on, it was an open game. The fans aren't too happy with Mowbray's 4-5-1, but it worked today and put both us and the players in good spirits for Sunday's game against the Villa.
