At last, we can now say with confidence who the best team in the world are. It is New Zealand. For the time being, at least. They might not be able to call themselves world champions (can they ever?), but once again they have won the Tri Nations, their fourth title in a row and their sixth in the past seven years, which means they are the best in the southern hemisphere. And without any credible challengers in the north the case must rest there, which hopefully makes them feel a bit better about themselves. Being the best rugby nation in the world means a lot to them down there.

This was quite a way to end the argument, a breathless game that brandished all that is best about southern-hemisphere rugby and, dare we say it, all that is best about the experimental law variations. Cynics will no doubt point to the preponderance of free-kicks, and there were a lot of those. Jonathan Kaplan was constantly awarding them at the breakdown, which was generally dominated by the All Blacks and Rodney So'oialo in particular. So there were a lot of tap-and-goes, which detracted a little from the shape so beloved of the traditionalists. Thank God they were not all penalties, though, might be another way of looking at it. Who knows who would have won?

As it is, we have ended up with the right winners, but in keeping with a Tri Nations that no one ever quite seized by the scruff of the neck, the All Blacks went about it the hard way. Despite looking reasonably comfortable with all that Australia could throw at them off the back of a dominant line-out in the first half and despite taking an early 7-0 lead in some style through a try by Mils Muliaina they contrived to go into the break 10-7 down.

Matt Giteau, in danger of becoming Australia's only real threat, slotted one of just two attempted penalty shots at goal in the game and then orchestrated the try that the Wallabies snatched on the stroke of half-time. His kick pass, as these cross-kicks are increasingly being called, was fielded by Peter Hynes, who flicked the ball inside to the rampaging Adam Ashley-Cooper. It looked suddenly as if the All Blacks were going to blow it again.

It looked even more like that a mere five minutes into the second half when James Horwill crashed over after a break by, you guessed it, Giteau. The side who had lost their previous match 53-8 were now 17-7 up and looking dangerously like winning the title. The glory of sport, some might have described it as; the utter insanity of these ridiculous laws might others.

But it was over to the Wallabies to show that they are every bit as capable of choking as the All Blacks, or maybe it was over to the All Blacks to put an end to this madness. Either way, the result was emphatic. Three tries followed for New Zealand in a little less than 20 minutes.

Tony Woodcock was a magnificent sight haring into the corner like a winger for his third try of the tournament, which brought New Zealand back to within three, before Piri Weepu was over after breaks by So'oialo and Sitiveni Sivivatu. The lead was New Zealand's again, and they went for the kill. Off a rare second-half line-out, Weepu was through and, from the next phase, Dan Carter, imperious as ever, waltzed through what was left of the defence.

The game was all but up, but Australia would not lie down. A try two minutes from time gave them hope and the All Blacks had to be as hard in defence as they have been in their last few games to keep the Aussies out. One final turnover long after the clock had run down gave Weepu the chance to belt the ball into the stands with gratitude.

It was a riveting climax to a tournament that has taken a while to get going (stretched in ungainly fashion across nine matches, it has had plenty of time to do it). No Mexican waves during this one, the atmosphere crackled throughout. At last, Australia were able to put up the sold-out signs some time in advance, although the bad news for those hoping to revive enthusiasm for rugby union in that country was that a lot of tickets were bought by New Zealand fans. They seemed to make at least as much noise as their hosts as the game built to its pitch.

So, New Zealand rugby is still alive after all. Ousted from the World Cup in the quarter-final, stripped of their best players by the wealthy clubs of the northern hemisphere and then committing the cardinal sin of losing twice in a row, things were looking bleak for Graham Henry and his charges less than two months ago. But the wise old owl did not panic and now the All Blacks have that mantle so dear to them. They are the best in the world. All they have to do now is make it so at the end of a World Cup final.

Georgios Samaras blamed the international break after Celtic raced into a commanding 4-0 lead, only to face a Motherwell fight back in the second. Samaras himself scored two to add to strikes from Shaun Maloney and Scott McDonald. But two goals in a two-minute spell after the break from John Sutton and David Clarkson gave some hope to the home side.

"The first 55 minutes, we played really good football, really great football," said Samaras. "We created a lot of chances, we had a really good tempo in our passes. But after that, I think our team was a little bit tired. A lot of players had a game in the middle of the week with their national teams and we lost our focus. Motherwell scored twice and just after that we were in a panic."

Celtic started the game with pace and purpose, with Samaras hailing the performance as the best he'd seen since arriving at the club. There was a zest about Celtic's start to the game, and in the fifth minute midfielder Scott Brown worked a one-two of sorts with Samaras on the right side and when his low cross sped across the Motherwell six-yard box leaving goalkeeper Graeme Smith stranded, Maloney was able to prod the ball into an empty net.

Three minutes later, with the home defence still trying to compose themselves, Samaras took a pass from McDonald, brushed past flailing home defender Mark Reynolds with some ease, and slotted the ball past Smith from 12 yards.

There was more misery for the Lanarkshire side when McDonald met a throw-in from Mark Wilson, spun and volleyed high past Smith from 16 yards.

Motherwell appeared paralysed. Chris Porter had the ball in the Celtic net just before the half-hour mark following a corner but was ruled offside.

Celtic were in complete control but Artur Boruc had to be quick off his line in the 33rd minute to deny Sutton after the former St Mirren striker had linked up well with Clarkson.

In the 37th minute, after Brown was fouled by Paul Quinn at the edge of the Motherwell box, Maloney cracked the bar with the resultant free-kick.

But the rampant champions were not to be denied a fourth before the break, and in the 41st minute Samaras finished off a seven-man move by racing on to McDonald's flick to again bury the ball past Smith.

Celtic should have been five ahead three minutes after the restart when Brown set up Maloney but the former Aston Villa man tried to walk the ball into the net and was eventually thwarted.

There looked no way back for Motherwell but Sutton pulled a goal back in the 55th minute after midfielder Keith Lasley had put Celtic defender Gary Caldwell under pressure in the box, the former St Mirren man driving past Boruc from 14 yards.

Two minutes later the home side reduced the deficit further when Stephen Hughes sent Clarkson through and the Scotland striker held off Celtic captain Stephen McManus to toe-poke the ball under Boruc.

The tide had turned, the Fir Park men were in the ascendancy and following a whipped-in cross from Hughes, Porter had a point-blank header saved by Boruc.

Celtic had lost their impetus but with a two-goal lead, the points still seemed secure.

In the 78th minute Boruc produced a brilliant reflex save from Clarkson's header - seconds before Porter failed to connect properly in front of goal, the ball skidding wide of the target.

Motherwell, though, lost belief in the final minutes and Celtic ran out comfortable winners, deserving the three points for their first-half performance alone.

Motherwell boss Mark McGhee admitted his side were taken apart in the first half.

"I thought Celtic were excellent. They outpowered us, they outplayed us, they outclassed us big time," McGhee said.

"I think it was a really good Celtic team in that first half that probably would've taken three or four goals against most teams in the SPL today."

McGhee insisted he had no thoughts of a stunning comeback at half-time.

"No matter what happened in the second half, the game's lost," he said.

"What we're trying to do is put things right in the second half.

"We did that but you could say what part did Celtic play in that, in terms of taking their foot off the accelerator?"

McGhee pulled no punches in his assessment of his side's defending, singling out Mark Reynolds for particular criticism.

"We were poor individually," he said. "It was nothing to do with systems. For the lad McDonald's goal, Mark Reynolds gets totally outmuscled - it was poor.

"I expect better of Mark Reynolds and he expects better of himself."

But McGhee, who insisted the result will have no bearing on Thursday's Uefa Cup clash with Nancy, praised his side's second-half fightback, saying: "I was pleased that they stayed as a team. I was pleased they didn't go disjointed."

Liverpool completed their first league win over Manchester United at Anfield in seven years as Ryan Babel struck the winner 13 minutes from time to complete a pulsating comeback.

When Carlos Tevez opened the scoring in the third minute it looked for all the world as though the champions would continue their impressive unbeaten league sequence against their fierce north-west rivals, but Wes Brown's first-half own goal and Babel's cameo performance gave Liverpool a long-awaited victory.

There was little that Brown, who scored the opening goal when these sides last met in the Premier League, could do about Liverpool's 27th-minute leveller. Nevertheless it allowed the hosts, playing without two of their most influential players in captain Steven Gerrard and Fernando Torres, to settle into a match that had threatened to race away from them. Babel's winning strike, when it came, followed an uncharacteristic mistake by Ryan Giggs, but it represented an appropriate end to a match the home side deserved to win. United's misery, on the other hand, was compounded by the dismissal of Nemanja Vidic for a second bookable offence.

Sir Alex Ferguson had wasted no time in awarding his new £30.75m signing Dimitar Berbatov his debut, accommodating the Bulgarian striker alongside Carlos Tevez and Wayne Rooney an attacking 4-3-3 formation, and the Scotsman's ambition was immediately rewarded as Berbatov, who had already seen a snapshot blocked by the hand of Martin Skrtel, set up the opening goal.

Berbatov, raced onto a clever first-time flick from Anderson, took on Jamie Carragher down the right and showed exemplary vision to cut the ball back from the byline to the unmarked Tevez, who planted a delicious first-time shot into the right-hand corner of the net before a stunned Kop.

The nightmare start for Liverpool fans was exacerbated by the sight of Gerrard and Torres on the bench, their manager Rafa Benítez having deemed them unworthy of risk, despite both recently-injured players having passed fitness tests on the eve of the match. However, with Javier Mascherano and man of the match Xavi Alonso excelling in midfield, Liverpool's leading lights were barely missed at all.

Inevitably, the early goal made for an exciting opening 20 minutes and Dirk Kuyt twice came close to an equaliser. The Dutchman fired narrowly over from distance in the fifth minute and, soon afterwards, was kicking himself when his poorly-struck close-range attempt enabled Edwin Van der Sar to make amends for teeing him up in the first place by flapping at a corner.

Van der Sar's reprieve was brief, however, as the former Netherlands goalkeeper handed the hosts a bizarre equaliser on 27 minutes. Perhaps United's three-man midfield also contributed to Alonso being afforded enough time to set his sights at goal and the Spain international let fly from 20 yards. The sting was taken out of the shot by Patrice Evra's deflection, but Van der Sar nonetheless contrived to palm the ball against the retreating Brown, who could only look on in dismay as the ball bobbled into the net.

United should have been ahead again within a minute as they sliced through the Liverpool midfield at pace, finding Anderson in space on the left. The Brazilian midfielder picked out Tevez, who poked the ball just over the bar from little more than six yards.

As the match wore on, though, Liverpool began to dominate possession, reassured by their fortunate respite and enjoying the extra space in midfield. A frustrated Tevez was booked for a lunge on Álvaro Arbeloa while an injury to Michael Carrick saw the England international replaced at half-time by Giggs.

Although the build-up to the match had been dominated by Berbatov, it was Liverpool's less vaunted debutant Albert Riera, who looked the livelier of the two. The Spaniard began to find increasing room down the left flank and United had to be alert to the his teasing cross, bound for Kuyt lurking at the far post, shortly after the restart.

Yossi Benayoun also enjoyed a productive match and was denied by Van der Sar on 53 minutes, when Alonso played him through with a deft lofted pass. The Israeli showed good control to bring the ball down but the rangy goalkeeper covered his near post well. The Reds were by now completely dominant, United seemingly struggling to calibrate their new system and reduced to a singular long shot from the ineffective Paul Scholes who was replaced midway through the second period.

But for all their good approach play, the Reds could not find their cutting edge, Robbie Keane epitomising their plight by producing an air kick when all had to do to score was connect with Mascherano's low cross-shot. Benítez decided to bring on Gerrard to remedy the situation but he almost cost his side a goal, when ceding possession to Giggs whose 25-yarder needed to be tipped over by Pepe Reina.

Despite all his experience Giggs would be at fault for Liverpool's winner, while it was Liverpool's other substitute Ryan Babel who was to score it. Attempting vainly to shepherd the ball out for a goal-kick Giggs was dispossessed by Mascherano, Kuyt picked up the loose ball and picked out Babel who sidefooted calmly past a clutch of defenders.

As United surged forwards in search of the equaliser they become evermore exposed at the back. Vidic and Nani were both was booked for fouls on Mascherano and Keane, Kuyt was denied by a reflex save by Van der Sar and then, with two minutes left, Vidic was shown a second yellow for leading with his arm on Alonso.

Darren Kenny won his fourth gold medal of the Paralympic Games as Great Britain celebrated four successes in Beijing. Danielle Brown and John Stubbs also struck gold at the Olympic Green Archery Field while a glorious Games for Britain's cyclists continued on the road, with cyclist David Stone adding a second victory in as many days with another powerful performance.

Kenny finished top of the podium on three occasions as Britain's cyclists won 12 out of 13 events entered at the Laoshan Velodrome earlier this week. The 38-year-old from Dorset, who has cerebral palsy, placed second in the men's individual time-trial CP3 on day six, but bounced back on day seven to go one better than he did in Athens in the men's road race.

Kenny held off the challenge of time-trial gold medallist Javier Ochoa, a former Tour de France rider, to win in one hour 37 minutes 00.74 seconds, 1.74secs clear of the Spaniard. Britain's 37th gold of the Games and the 17th by a British cyclist, moved them to within one behind gold medal of hosts China.

In the archery Brown, from Lothersdale, North Yorkshire, secured an emphatic 14-point victory over Japan's Chieko Kamiya in the final of the women's open individual compound. The 20-year-old world champion shot six maximums into the gold target to her opponent's one for Britain's first title of day seven. "I just went out there shooting," said Brown. "It is my first Paralympics and I really wanted to get the gold. I don't think it's sunk in yet but I'm really happy. I had one dodgy arrow but otherwise it was a good match."

Stubbs's second archery gold medal came in the men's individual compound open with a narrow victory over Alberto Simonelli. The 43-year-old from Warrington, who had most of his right leg amputated following a road accident at the age of 24, hit the golden maximum area eight times to his Italian oppenent's six to record a 116-111 victory in his first Paralympics.

Stone, meanwhile, rode to his second victory in two days with a powerful performance. The 27-year-old Leeds-based rider, who has cerebral palsy and uses a tricycle, crossed the line in 45 minutes 05.33 seconds, 3mins 27.52secs ahead of his nearest challenger to win the mixed individual road race CP1/CP2 title. Stone, who won the time-trial on day six, said: "It has been a very successful couple of days, really wonderful. This is what I've been working towards for a long time. I feel fantastic, amazing."

In the pool, Matt Walker won silver in the men's S7 50m butterfly as China took another gold through Tian Rong in a world record time of 30.37. The 30-year-old from Stockport, who has cerebral palsy, now has won a relay gold, two individual silvers and two bronze medals.

Team news we've whippped from the wires, which you'll probably have guessed from the line-ups anyway

Liverpool give new signing Albert Riera his debut in today's north-west derby against Manchester United - but Steven Gerrard and Fernando Torres are not risked any closer to the initial action than the bench.

Eyes front for the first email of the day

"Here we go again," writes Simon Hoyle. "They say that repeating the same action over and over but expecting a different outcome is one symptom of insanity; I sit here ready to watch Liverpool take on Man U and expecting - or
rather hoping, really - that Liverpool will a) manage to score a bloody goal, and b) win. Am I actually mad?"

Probably not, Simon. (Well, you might be. For all I know you could have woken up this morning in Broadmoor, painted yourself green, put a pair of antlers on your head and danced naked around your cell.) But there's nothing mad about hoping that Liverpool score a goal or even win. The law of averages would suggest they have to beat United some time soon, doesn't it? Doesn't it?

Not long now: With Tevez, Berbatov and Rooney providing the pointy ends of a three-pronged 4-3-3 Manchester United formation, it has to be said that this looks a very attack-minded Manchester United line-up. I'm predicting more than three goals, with Liverpool to win or at least get a draw. Those of you who are familiar with my work will already be on your way to the bookies to back a Liverpool 0-1 Manchester United correct score.

1 min: Liverpool line-up in their usual home strip of fire-engine red. Manchester United's players are wearing virginal white shirts, shorts and socks. It's like good versus evil ... the Red Devils kick off and immediately concede a throw-in.

2 min: Having lined up wide on the right, Rooney brings the ball down the right flank and dinks it to Tevez, who drives a low cross in to the penalty area. Berbatov gets on the end of it and only a timely intervention from Alvaro Arbeloa prevents him from scoring with his first shot in anger for Manchester United.

GOAL! Liverpool 0-1 Manchester United (Tevez 3) Tevez fires Manchester United into an early lead, having started and finished the move that led to the goal. From midfield, he picked out Dimitar Berbatov down in the Liverpool left-back area. The Bulgarian turned Javier Mascherano inside-out and returned the favour with a cross from the bye-line, allowing Tevez to rifle the ball past Reina in the Liverpool goal. I'm not sure who was supposed to be tracking his run, but whoever it is will be on the wrong end of a serious Rafa Benitez wigging at half time.

8 min: It's all Manchester United at the moment and Liverpool's defence is looking very shaky. Having been stunned into silence by United's early goal, the denizens of the Kop appear to have found their voice again.

10 min: Scholes and Evra combine well down the left, before teeing up Anderson, who sends in a cross. It's blocked at the near post and Liverpool clear their lines.

11 min: Liverpool win a corner, even though the ball came off Alvaro Arbeloa before crossing the white line. It's swung in from the right and drops under the cross-bar. Van der Sar drops it and Kuyt attempts to smash the loose ball into the back of the net from five yards out, only to see his effort blocked by a part of Wes Brown's anatomy that may well have been his arm. Manchester United hack clear. This is great stuff.

12 min: Liverpool have a raucous penalty appeal emphatically turned down by Howard Webb.

14 min: Liverpool sweep forward, with Yossi Benayoun on the ball about 15 yards outside the Manchester United penalty area. He feeds Liverpool debutant Alberto Riera, who is promptly dispossessed by Wes Brown.

15 min: Replays show that Dirk Kuyt's miss from five yards was not a Wes Brown handball - it was in fact an excellent save from Van der Sar, who despite being on the ground, managed to spread himself and keep the ball out. Of course if Kuyt hadn't made it quite so easy for him by smashing the ball downwards the goalkeeper would have had no chance.

19 min: As Liverpool substitute Steven Gerrard warms up on the touchline, Manchester United go forward again. Berbatov is outnumbered on the right touchline and dispossessed by Alberto Riera.

20 min: Howard Webb reaches into his pocket, pulls out his trusty yellow card and waves it in the direction of Carlos Tevez. The Argentinian's indiscretion? An ill-advised and poorly-timed lunge at Alvaro Arbeloa. He takes his punishment without complaint.

23 min: Liverpool enjoy another decent share of the possession, but without troubling the Manchester United back four unduly. Apart from that corner where Van der Sar dropped the ball, they haven't given Messrs Brown, Ferdinand, Vidic and Evra too much to worry about at all so far.

GOAL! Liverpool 1-1 Manchester United (Brown og) Good God, that was astonishingly inept. With Liverpool attempting to breach the United defence again, Xabi Alonso sent a speculative up-and-under into the Manchester United box. In no real danger, Edwin van der Sar flies off his line in a bid to slap the ball clear from the edge of the six-yard box, but his attempted clearance bounces off Wes Brown and rolls into the goal. That's a shocker.

29 min: While I was stitching my sides back together and strapping on my whalebone corset, Carlos Tevez missed an excellent opportunity to put Manchester United back in front. I've said it before and I'll say it again, this is an absolute belter of a football match. Let's hope it continues in this vein.

31 min: Free-kick to Manchester United, about 30 yards out, not too far right of centre. Anderson and Berbatov stand over it, before the Brazilian curls his effort into the wall.

32 mins: Another Liverpool attack down the right flank. Yossi Benayoun tees up Robbie Keane, who pulls the trigger and kicks the kind of fresh-air shot from the edge of the penalty area that any golf club hacker would be embarrassed by.

37 min: Manchester United win a corner, which Liverpool clear before launching a counter-attack that's broken up by a limping Michael Carrick. He doesn't look like he'll last much longer in this game.

40 min: A marvellous tackle from Jamie Carragher puts a stop to the gallop of Dimitar Berbatov.

42 min: From the edge of the penalty area, Michael Carrick tries to tee up Wayne Rooney when it looked like the shot was the better option. I suspect he was in too much pain to try a screamer from that far. His injury can also be attributed to Edwin van der Sar, who's having the afternoon of nightmares. The Man Utd goalkeeper threw the ball out to Carrick but put too much elbow on it, gave his team-mate far too much to do to win possession, and after stretching in a bid to beat Yosi Benayoun to the loose ball he came out of the crunching challenge an emphatic second best.

45 min: Not long now until half-time. I'll be astonished if there aren't more goals in the second half, but I couldn't possibly hazard a guess as to which way they'll go.

Half-time: Actually that's a bit melodramatic. I could easily hazard a guess, but I don't want to. What's that you say? Oh, go on then. Liverpool to win 3-2, with Robbie Keane breaking his duck for the club at least once.

Half-time email: "Give yourself a pat on the back, a GU sports journo who isn't using this as an attempt to take the piss out of us [LFC] for 90mins. Well done. You're obviously off the medication today," writes Mawal T (or T Mawal), whose email goes a long way towards explaining exactly why it is that some people like taking the piss out of paranoid Liverpool supporters.

Speaking of football fans that people enjoy winding up, the word on the street is that Newcastle fans are set to demonstrate against the meltdown at their club by performing a giant conga around St James' Park this afternoon. A hokey cokey, if you will, a form of protest that sounds even more ridiculous if you attempt to say it in a Geordie accent. And to think they wonder why nobody takes them seriously.

46 min: Manchester United substitution: Ryan Giggs on, Michael Carrick on. Keane and Alonso kick off for Liverpool, attacking the Kop.

46 min: Carlos Tevez is frowning and shaking his head. Why? Because as he leaped in an attempt to get on the end of Ryan Giggs cross from the right, he gave Martin Skrtel a sly push in the small of the back and got caught by the referee, who gave Liverpool a free-kick. Tut-tut Carlito, naughty boy.

48 min: Without having carved out any decent scoring opportunities, Liverpool are definitely the sprightlier of the two sides in the early stages of the second half. Robbie Keane tries to pick out Dirk Kuyt in the Manchester United penalty area, but his pass from the right-hand side is too high for the Dutchman and drifts behind the incoming Yossi Benayoun.

51 mins: With Aurelio and Riera working well down the left-hand side for Liverpool, the latter attempts to send a cross into the Manchester United penalty area. He puts far too much weight on it and the ball threatens to knock a passing airplane out of the sky.

53 min: A Paul Scholes snap-shot from about 30 yards fizzes narrowly wide of Pepe Reina's left-hand post.

53 min: Another promising Liverpool attack comes to nowt when, with better options open either side of him, Dirk Kuyt shoots feebly from distance, making it easy for Edwin va der Sar.

55 min: Good work from Yossi Benayoun, who does well to stay onside, ghost in behind Patrice Evra and win a corner off Edwin van der Sar. From the ensuing inswinger, the ball drops kindly for Robbie Keane, who attempts to slot the ball home, only to see his effort scuffed comically wide.

57 min: "Us Espanyol fans are still chuckling over the fact that a big cry-baby like Riera conned Liverpool into paying actually cold hard money for him!" writes Tom in Barcelona. "We miss him and his wayward crossing, lazy play and shocking attitude so much. Cue: Riera dribbling past 10 Manchester United players and banging in an absolute screamer."

59 min: Free-kick for Manchester United wide on the left, about halfway inside the Liverpool half. Ryan Giggs swings it towards the far corner of the six yard box, Pepe Reina comes for it, fails to catch cleanly and ends up chasing the ball towards the sideline, from where he hoofs it up the field.

61 min: Martin Skrtel unleashes a surface-to-air screamer from 25 yards, but shoots straight at Van der Sar, who escapes with only his palms stung.

62 min: If I was a betting man, which I am, and had money on Liverpool to get a result in this game, which I do, I'd be very satisfied at the moment. They're comfortably controlling midfield and vastly superior to Manchester United so far in this second half.

64 min: Manchester United substitution: Scholes off, Owen Hargreaves on. John McCaughey thinks he might know why Newcastle's fans are going to hokey cokey their way around St James' Park this afternoon. "Perhaps it's called having a sense of humour," he suggests. "Try it sometime." It's an interesting theory, but if Newcastle supporters have a sense of humour, why would they want to protest about anything that's going on at their club?

67 min: Liverpool substitution: Yossi Benayoun, who's played very well today, off. Steven Gerrard on.

68 min: From the left, Ryan Giggs drills a low cross into the Liverpool penalty area. It's a yard behind Rooney and Tevez. Moments later, Steven Gerrard gives the ball away to Ryan Giggs, who tries an audacious chip from distance. Pepe Reina performs heroics to prevent a magnificent effort from dropping under the crossbar.

70 min: "If I were a betting man, I'd bet on Liverpool controlling the entire second half, only to concede a faintly tragi-comical goal at the end. So, I'm feeling sickeningly comfortable right now," writes Gareth Barry. Actually scrap that, it's Gareth Parry.

71 mins: Liverpool substitution: Alberto Riero off, Ryan Babel on. From the right flank, Dirk Kuyt sends a cross into the Manchester United penalty area, but his delivery is too high.

73 min: Another cross into the Manchester United penalty area, this time from Javier Mascherano on the left-hand side of the sward. Patrice Evra clears with a meaty header.

75 min: Alonso sends the ball wide to Dirk Kuyt doeep in the Manchester United left-back territory. He heads downwards, prompting Nemanja Vidic to hack clear.

GOAL! Liverpool 2-1 Manchester United (Babel 76) Super-sub Ryan Babel smashes the ball into the roof of the Manchester United net from 15 yards after being teed up perfectly by Dirk Kuyt. Abject defending from Ryan Giggs on the byline, who could easily have prodded the ball out for a corner, allowed Javier Mascherano to scurry behind him and pull the ball back to Kuyt.

78 min: Nemanja Vidic gets a yellow card (and looks relieved to escape a red one) when he fouls Keane a few yards outside the Manchester United penalty area when it looked as if the Irish striker had only the goalkeeper to beat.

81 min: Manchester United are in total disarray and Liverpool are going all out for a third goal. They win a corner, from which nothing comes.

83 min: Manchester United substitution that took place about five or 10 minutes ago: Nani on, Anderson off. For the record, Ryan Babel has just become the first Liverpool player to score against Manchester United since Harry Kewell did so in 1748.

86 min: Liverpool substitution: Sami Hyypia on, Javier Mascherano off.

88 min: Three minutes to go and Liverpool are about to knock Manchester United off their perch ... for the time being at least. United win a throw-in deep in Liverpool territory, but Alonso wins possession back and alleviates the pressure on the home side.

90 min: With his arms up, Nemanja Vidic clatters Xabi Alonso in an aerial collision. Howard Webb blows his whistle, brandishes his yellow card and, after a short pause and possibly a reminder from one or two Liverpool players, remembers to brandish the red.

Vidic is off for his second bookable offence. On the Manchester United bench, Sir Alex Ferguson has a face like thunder. It's on days like this that footballers earn their big money. If I was Giggs, Vidic, Scholes or Van der Sar, you couldn't pay me enough money to go into the Manchester United dressing room to face the hairdryer after this game. Quite how Wayne Rooney feels about all this is anyone's guess. He's been marooned out on the right touchline for the entire game and looks destined to stay there for the foreseeable future barring an injury to Berbatov.

90 +3 min: With Dirk Kuyt and Robbie Keane both having missed good chances to increase Liverpool's lead, Manchester United win a corner, which is wasted. Shortly afterwards, Rooney drags a long-range effort wide of the post.

90+4 min Peep! Peep! Peep! Howard Webb brings proceedings to a close with three shrill blasts of his whistle, prompting raucous celebrations from Liverpool's players and supporters. Make no mistake, this wasn't hype. This ... was ... a ... big ... game. They thoroughly deserved their win having been the vastly superior team throughout the second half. Billions of pounds currently spent on inspecting schools and testing pupils will be redirected to reward those schools teaching the most disadvantaged children in society under Liberal Democrat plans to be announce tomorrow.

The party's existing plans for a "pupil premium", paid to schools for every child they educate from the poorest households, will be doubled to £5bn by cutting back on central government spending, the party's education spokesman, David Laws, will tell the Lib Dem conference in Bournemouth tomorrow.

The entire education system should be liberalised to give every state school the freedoms enjoyed by academies and private schools, he told the Guardian ahead of his conference speech. Heaping praise on the independent sector's traditional curricula, he argued that the national curriculum should be removed in state schools so teachers are free to decide how pupils are taught.

"We think that the national curriculum is suffocatingly detailed and prescriptive and the way that it integrates with the control that is exercised and the influence that is exercised by government in relation to what is taught in exams is stultifying.

"The consensus about that is very broad. It's not only the NUT and the left in education saying these things, the evidence that we get from the very poshest public schools in Britain is all confirming that they feel the education system we've got today both through the curriculum and examinations system is narrowing education unnecessarily and making it more difficult to inspire … the youngsters in the classroom."

He will tell the conference that the pupil premium is the "dynamite designed to explode the iron curtain of inequality". There are currently several review groups within the party overhauling their education policies, the results of which will be announced in the party's spring conference. But the review will include an expansion of the pupil premium idea, he said. The money would come from cutting back on the central government education budget - understood to be about 18% of the £50bn annual total.
He told the Guardian they were currently devising plans to make some of those savings by scaling back the work of Ofsted, the schools inspectorate, and scrapping Sats for 14-year olds, freeing up some of the £700m spent on testing every year.

He said they would not dictate how schools spent the extra money they got through the pupil premium but they were strongly in favour of moves in some academies to extend the school day, shorten the summer holidays and open on Saturdays to give pupils more teaching time throughout the school year.

Laws, who was educated at the fee-charging school St George's college in Weybridge, praised the independent sector saying: "I think that the maintained system has a lot of learn from the private system, not based on the assumption that private schools get brilliant results, because it's not really surprising that they get results much better than the maintained sector given that the youngsters who enter those schools come from - generally speaking - advantaged backgrounds, with very supportive parents, and with a lot of characteristics which mean they are likely to do well.
"The two things that we can really learn from the independent sector is that incessant government micro-management is not necessarily what creates a high performing and healthy education. I think the independent sector benefits from the additional distance it has from government and from state directives and dictates. Those principals of greater independence and freedom we want to see for all schools."

He said they also had a lot to learn in terms of expenditure and that extra money into education should not be regarded as an "extravagance", particularly because people are so willing to pay thousands of pounds for a private education.

"It's really necessary to give those youngsters from deprived backgrounds a chance. If it's necessary for all those pupils with inherited advantage, how much more necessarily is it for that funding for youngsters with disadvantages," he said.

Laws is due to make his speech at 10.15am tomorrow.
